Author: froo
Content:
I agree with most of the points presented, but I just cannot agree with point 2. In fact, the second point comes across as more like hey-you're-awesome mumbo jumbo that I would expect from motivational speakers.

"Good ideas alter the power balance in relationships, that is why good ideas are always initially resisted"

I don't think a blanket statement like they are always resisted is quite true. For example, a simple test would be:

2 people are caught in a house fire, person A says "lets get out of here"... person B would have to say "no, lets stay here" for this statement to be true.

Similarly ideas can be resisted because they are actually bad ideas.

If anything, I would say that people are more or less resistant to change, unless there are very obvious reasons for change.

Author: qhoxie
Title: Ask YC: Distributed Column DB Comparison
Content: I am interested to hear thoughts and experiences with the various emerging solutions.  HBase, Couch, Hypertable, Simple, etc.

Author: ivank
Content: One of Steam's biggest value-adds for me is that I don't have to reinstall or manually update any games. There's no registry cruft, so you can move the Steam folder across Windows installs.

Author: fauigerzigerk
Content:
It seems there are two conflicting trends that affect the use of threads for parallelism: One is that the amount RAM available to a typical machine grows fast and thus in-memory data processing becomes more important. The other trend is that some smart people prefer a process model over threads, which excludes working with a lot of in-memory data or at least makes it hugely more complex (working with shared memory blobs, no pointers, none of the usual data structures, etc).

I for one feel very restricted by languages like Python, Ruby or PHP because they effectively force me to use the process model for parallelism and prevent easy sharing of in-memory data structures between threads. So even though I like these languages I use C#, Java or C++ for most projects. Others may of course have different scenarios and different requirements.
